node.title: Segmentation fault(core dumped)
node.bodyText:
I'm running Moose in dual boot mode Linux
I have followed all the guidelines for Moose installation and create Moose environment successfully.
But unable to launch peacock gui
I have tried both path

Home/project/Moose/gui
Home/project/Moose/python/peacock

Both contain executable
I tried running command in both their own directory including their executable
Even tried in my app which contains Moose opdt example executable
I tried this while remaining in Moose framework
Earlier tried getting same things done in peacock environment as well

node.title: Error with Custom Spatially Varying Elastic Moduli Material
node.bodyText:
Hi experts,
I'm encountering an error while running an input file for my custom material. The material computes a spatially varying elastic tensor. Not sure what is going on...
Please find the material files, a minimal example, and log files in debug mode.
Files

Hello
my guess without having run your code is that the residualSetup routine for the derived class needs to call the residualSetup for the parent class first.
If it s not that, please run your input in a debugger and get us the exact line for the "out of bounds" error that you receive currently.
Guillaume

Thank you! So, I added a line in the constructor to call the residualSetup function of the base class ComputeElasticityTensorBase:
`template <bool is_ad, typename T>
void
IsotropicElasticModulusFromVarTempl<is_ad, T>::residualSetup()
{
// Call residualSetup of base class
ComputeElasticityTensorBaseTempl<is_ad, T>::residualSetup();`
However, this didn't work. The backtrace of the debugger is in the file named backtrace.txt, accessible through this link

can you update IsotropicElasticModulusFromVar.C on your repo? The backtrace points to a wrong line currently.
You should check:

which material properties are being accessed in your material
which material properties are resized in ComputeElasticityTensorBaseTempl
Im sorry, should be updated now. Could it MooseArray<double>::operator[] the issue?
That operator is indexing into the array of the material properties at the index of the quadrature point. And for some reason, that material property has not been initialized, the size is too small

ok nevermind.
it looks to me like the seg fault is happening when accessing the variable values.

so with that in mind, is residualSetup the right place for what you are doing?
Residual setup is not in a quadrature point loop maybe?
I think you may be wanting to override another material property routine.
Is _cijk supposed to depend on space? Isnt it a constant in the base class?

Hi @GiudGiud
Thank you! Yeah the issue was that I didnt need to override residualSetup. I removed it and it worked ;)

node.title: Issues with "app_type = ThermalHydraulicsApp"
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am new to MOOSE and I am trying to learn from the example (link below) CoupledHeatTransferAction in coupling to develope a model that couples heat transfer and thermal hydraulics.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/CoupledHeatTransferAction.html
However, I am having the following error:
*** ERROR ***
"ThermalHydraulicsApp" is not a registered application name.
No search paths were set. We made no attempts to locate the corresponding library file.
Make sure you have compiled the library and either set the "library_path" variable in your input file or exported "MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH".
I have both the thermal_hydraulics and the heat_transfer packages active in the makefile, and both work fine in other practices.
I also tried to dynamically register the object, by the following:
[Problem]
register_objects_from = 'ThermalHydraulicsApp'
library_path = '../thermal_hydraulics/lib'
[]
and still the outcome is the same.
The only time this inputs run, is when I remove "app_type = ThermalHydraulicsApp", but then I am concerned if the heat transfer is captured properly.
What do you recommend me to do to overcome this issue?

Hello
which executable are you using ?
specifying the app type has no incidence on the results. It s a micro optimization
Guillaume

Oh Thank you so much for answering, so it is not big deal if it is not working.
Sorry what do you mean by "excutable"? I am using Linux ubuntu (terminal in windows), and activate MOOSE through Conda, does this help answering your question?

The executable is the -opt file you use to run your inputs
On windows they are .exe files
Thank you for the clarification, yes it is -opt excutable.

node.title: Refining a specific region of an existing mesh
node.bodyText:
I am trying to refine a specific region of an existing mesh (will eventually go for adaptive mesh refinement, so any tips on that appreciated, but for now attempting to do it manually) which has blocks and materials and everything already assigned. I have used SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator to assign the regions in question to new block numbers and refine only those blocks, but they don't have any of the properties assigned to the original mesh.
Essentially I have 2 touching blocks made from different materials, and I want to refine a volume that contains a small part of both blocks and the interface between them, so I want to define a new block containing only this region where the elements still have the same properties they'd have had before the new block existed.
Is there a way to transfer these properties automatically, or a better way to do this in general?

Hello
Changing the subdomains will be problematic as material properties are assigned to a subdomain.

I want to refine a volume that contains a small part of both blocks and the interface between them, so I want to define a new block containing only this region where the elements still have the same properties they'd have had before the new block existed.

You could try:

use two new subdomains for this purpose. One for each of the sub-parts of each block. And change the block-restriction of the original materials on the original blocks to include the new blocks.
use a different refinement technique. AMR is definitely a good way to do this. You could also try to refine the interface using a RefineSidesetGenerator?

Hi,
Thank you for that, I have attempted to use AMR now and it seems to work initially but then the supercomputer kills it with signal 9 due to lack of memory. My first thought was to split the mesh to reduce the load, but does this refinement work with a pre-split mesh?

hello
AMR works with pre-split meshes, no problem there

No idea how it should look like, does not look completely wrong.
I could continue without initializing now - is that viable or a really bad idea? What does conda init even do apart from putting a block of code into .bashrc?

Should be the moose environment in the prompt.
You could just delete conda and re install. It takes a lot less time than trying to fix it. Make sure to use the miniforge one we point to in our website

Should be the moose environment in the prompt.
You could just delete conda and re install. It takes a lot less time than trying to fix it. Make sure to use the miniforge one we point to in our documentation

It should show as (moose) in the console prompt if you installed conda and ran conda init then activated the moose environment.
And the list should contain a few moose- prefixed packages that are the dependencies of moose
i don’t know all that conda init does. You can probably find out in the conda documentation

I used exactly the command from the moose install page. I also deleted and reinstalled it several times and tried  two different PCs. The error is persistent.
The different environment (instead of (moose) ) is due to the fact, that I did not continue with installation after conda init failed.
However, being curious and impatient, I did exactly that in the meantime: Ignore the conda init completely and just use it. And it seems to work fine. It's a bit scary, because this is clearly not the intended way - but I am not really motivated to experiment now, because I fear messing up a working state.

Sorry for the delayed response, it was our three day weekend.

export PATH=/home/stud/rschwa/miniforge/bin:$PATH
source activate /home/stud/rschwa/miniforge
conda info --all
conda list

You did exactly what I asked, and your print out is exactly what I expected (there shouldn't be any (moose) prompt). And it worked. So at least we have a work-around in the event we can't figure out conda init.
Next, lets do create the moose environment and see if we can activate that:
export PATH=/home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge/bin:$PATH
source activate /home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda create -n moose moose-dev
source activate /home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge/envs/moose
If Conda successfully activate the moose environment, you should be able to build/run MOOSE. But I think the issue still remains "why doesn't conda init bash work". Does it now? After everything we've done?
conda init bash

rschwa@syrinx:~$ echo $PATH
/home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games:/afs/tu-chemnitz.de/home/urz/r/rschwa/:/afs/tu-chemnitz.de/home/urz/r/rschwa/bin
rschwa@syrinx:~$ source activate /home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge/envs/moose
(moose) rschwa@syrinx:~$

Works fine, and compiling and using moose does work as well. So this works as workaround.
However, conda init bash still fails with exactly the same error as shown above (I will save the space for quoting it again).
Also, just conda init moose fails with the message Please call conda init first - but the command you gave me above using source activate works.

For your peace of mind, all of our build machines running the show here: https://civet.inl.gov, are using the same methods to activate the moose environment as you are at this point. Its a very clean way to do it. that is: it won't pick up anything stray from your bash/zsh/tcsh profiles by accident (and that is why we do it in our build environments).
Anyways! Not being able to run conda activate as a regular user is quite the inconvenience! Can we look at your bash (or whatever shell you are using) profiles? I think that would be the next logical step.
To prove if it is actually an environment profile issue getting in the way, does this work:
env -i bash --norc --noprofile
# some needed stuff
export HOME=/home/stud_syrinx
export PATH=/bin:/usr/bin:/sbin
export TERM=xterm-256color

# and now the troubleshooting:
export PATH=/home/stud_syrinx/rschwa/miniforge/bin:$PATH
conda init bash
Something I want to point out:

Also, just conda init moose

I am not sure this is a valid command to be honest. conda init <insert your terminal shell type here> is what should follow the init argument. Be it, ZSH, TCSH, BASH, etc type shells.

node.title: PETSc Preconditioners
node.bodyText: PETSc appears to have many options for preconditioners. Are all of the PETSc preconditioners implemented for use in MOOSE?

We do very little hard-coding of solve related options in MOOSE related to PETSc such that users should have almost complete accessibility to PETSc preconditioning options through PETSc command line options, e.g. -pc_type hypre -pc_hypre_type boomeramg, -pc_type gamg, -pc_type lu, -pc_type asm, -pc_type bjacobi, -pc_type jacobi, so on and so forth

I should have known you'd go straight to the hard one 😄 I should perhaps say we have complete accessibility to algebraic preconditioners, including algebraic multigrid, but we do not have the hooks currently for geometric multigrid. Our parent library libMesh has demonstrated geometric multigrid (see libMesh/libmesh#1567 and libMesh/libmesh#2047) but we have not done so in MOOSE yet. However, doing so is a desire of @roystgnr and mine. I just wrote it into our NEAMS 5-year plan ... so it's probably not going to happen immediately

node.bodyText:

How to calculate the total mass of the liquid infiltration in the porous medium per time step?
Below is the input file for 05.i in the tutorial:
Darcy flow with heat advection and conduction, using Water97 properties

[]
[]

[]
[Variables]

[]

[]
[]

[BCs]

[]

[]
[]

[]
[biot_modulus]

[]
[permeability_aquifer]

[]

[]

[]
[]

[basic]
type = SMP
full = true

petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type -pc_asm_overlap'

[]

[]

end_time = 1E6
dt = 1E5
nl_abs_tol = 1E-10
[]
[Outputs]

[]
Thanks

Hello
create an auxiliary variable or a material property that is equal to the local fluid density. There should be one computed by the module already. Use Debug/show_material_props to see what properties are being defined.
Then use a postprocessor that does an element-wise integration of the material property over the domain. It will be named something like
ElementMaterialPropertyIntgral, you ll have to check the exact name
Guillaume
We have a PorousFlowFluidMass postprocessor that should do what you want https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/PorousFlowFluidMass.html

Hello cpgr
What physical quantity is calculated by PorousFlowFluidMass postprocessor, and in what units?
Thanks

Mass, computed as the product of fluid density, saturation and porosity integrated over the block. You can choose which fluid component, which phases etc.
The units are mass units, which is most likely kg (as the fluid properties used give density in kg/m3)

node.title: Convergence problem encountered when calculating contact
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm simulating a thermodynamic coupling problem, and my geometry model is a two cylindrical geometry with a gap. I've set the grid in RZ coordinates for ease of calculation. In the process of calculation, the gap would go from no contact to contact, and in the process I ran into convergence problems.
I set the penalty in the contact module [gap_contact] and output volume of the gap. If I set penalty large it would be not converged. On the contrary the volume of the gap becomes negative which I think the reason is the penalty factor too small the inner cylinder seeps into the outside. At last I set penalty 6.7e7 the volume would not be negative but there is a convergence problem. It would shorten the time step until it crashed. I upload the input/output file and mesh there.
https://github.com/jin0123456/miniature-system
Hope someone can give me some advice. Much appreciated.

Hello
i think this is a known issue with penalty based approaches. If the penalty is too small, penetration can happen, if it s too large, the conditioning of the matrix takes a hit and it becomes difficult to solve the equations.
I think moose has Lagrange-multiplier and mortar based approaches to contact. You could try those?
Guillajme

Thanks for your advice. I have solved this problem by using mortar based approach.
By the way, can this approach be used on 3D geometry? Is the effect good?

Hello
We have 3D mortar as of 18 months ago. Please feel free to try it
I see. Much appreciated.
